#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER II
#Text=DURING dinner both Ruth and
#Text=Ethel were aware of some sub-interest in the Judge ’s manner ; his absent-mindedness was unusual , and once Ruth saw a faint smile that nothing evident could have induced .

#Text=Unconsciously also he set a tone of constraint and hurry ; the meal was not loitered over , the conversation flagged , and all rose from the table with a sense of relief ; perhaps , indeed , with a feeling of expectation .
#Text=They entered the parlor together , and the mastiff rose to meet them , asking permission to remain with the little coaxing push of his nose which brought the ready answer :
#Text=“ Certainly , Sultan .
#Text=Make yourself comfortable . ”
#Text=Then they grouped themselves round the fire , and the Judge lit his cigar and looked at Ethel in a way that instantly brought curiosity to the question :
#Text=“ You have a secret , father , ” she said .
#Text=“ Is it about grandmother ? ”
#Text=“ It is news rather than a secret , Ethel .
#Text=And grandmother has a good deal to do with it , for it is about her family -- the Mostyns . ”
#Text=“ Oh ! ”
#Text=The tone of Ethel ’s “ Oh ! ” was not encouraging , and Ruth ’s look of interest held in abeyance was just as chilling .

#Text=But something like this attitude had been expected , and Judge Rawdon was not discouraged by it ; he knew that youth is capable of great and sudden changes , and that its ability to find reasonable motives for them is unlimited , so he calmly continued :
#Text=“ You are aware that your grandmother ’s name before marriage was Rachel Mostyn ? ”
#Text=“ I have seen it a thousand times at the bottom of her sampler , father , the one that is framed and hanging in her morning room -- Rachel Mostyn , November , Anno Domini , 1827 . ”
#Text=“ Very well .
#Text=She married George Rawdon , and they came to New York in 1834 .
#Text=They had a pretty house on the Bowling Green and lived very happily there .
#Text=I was born in 1850 , the youngest of their children .
#Text=You know that I sign my name Edward M. Rawdon ; it is really Edward Mostyn Rawdon . ”
#Text=He paused , and Ruth said , “ I suppose Mrs. Rawdon has had some news from her old home ? ”
#Text=“ She had a letter last night , and I shall probably receive one to-morrow .
#Text=Frederick Mostyn , her grand-nephew , is coming to New York , and Squire Rawdon , of Rawdon Manor , writes to recommend the young man to our hospitality . ”
#Text=“ But you surely do not intend to invite him here , Edward .
#Text=I think that would not do . ”
#Text=“ He is going to the Holland House .
#Text=But he is our kinsman , and therefore we must be hospitable . ”
#Text=“ I have been trying to count the kinship .
#Text=It is out of my reckoning , ” said Ethel .
#Text=“ I hope at least he is nice and presentable . ”
#Text=“ The Mostyns are a handsome family .
#Text=Look at your grandmother .
#Text=And Squire Rawdon speaks very well of Mr. Mostyn .
#Text=He has taken the right side in politics , and is likely to make his mark .
#Text=They were always great sportsmen , and I dare say this representative of the family is a good-looking fellow , well-mannered , and perfectly dressed . ”
#Text=Ethel laughed .
#Text=“ If his clothes fit him he will be an English wonder .
#Text=I have seen lots of Englishmen ; they are all frights as to trousers and vests .
#Text=There was Lord Wycomb , his broadcloths and satins and linen were marvels in quality , but the make !
#Text=The girls hated to be seen walking with him , and he would walk -- ‘good for the constitution , ’ was his explanation for all his peculiarities .
#Text=The Caylers were weary to death of them . ”
#Text=“ And yet , ” said Ruth , “ they sang songs of triumph when Lou Cayler married him . ”
#Text=“ That was a different thing .
#Text=Lou would make him get ‘ fits ’ and stop wearing sloppy , baggy arrangements .
#Text=And I do not suppose the English lord has now a single peculiarity left , unless it be his constitutional walk -- that , of course .
#Text=I have heard English babies get out of their cradles to take a constitutional . ”
#Text=During this tirade Ruth had been thinking .
#Text=“ Edward , ” she asked , “ why does Squire Rawdon introduce Mr. Mostyn ?
#Text=Their relationship cannot be worth counting . ”
#Text=“ There you are wrong , Ruth . ”
#Text=He spoke with a little excitement .
#Text=“ Englishmen never deny matrimonial relationships , if they are worthy ones .
#Text=Mostyn and Rawdon are bound together by many a gold wedding ring ; we reckon such ties relationships .
#Text=Squire Raw-don lost his son and his two grandsons a year ago .
#Text=Perhaps this young man may eventually stand in their place .
#Text=The Squire is nearly eighty years old ; he is the last of the English Rawdons -- at least of our branch of it . ”
#Text=“ You suppose this Mr. Mostyn may become Squire of Rawdon Manor ? ”
#Text=“ He may , Ruth , but it is not certain .
#Text=There is a large mortgage on the Manor . ”
#Text=“ Oh ! ”
#Text=Both girls made the ejaculation at the same moment , and in both voices there was the same curious tone of speculation .
#Text=It was a cry after truth apprehended , but not realized .
#Text=Mr. Rawdon remained silent ; he was debating with himself the advisability of further confidence , but he came quickly to the conclusion that enough had been told for the present .
#Text=Turning to Ethel , he said :
#Text=“ I suppose girls have a code of honor about their secrets .
#Text=Is Dora Denning ’s ‘ extraordinary news ’ shut up in it ? ”
#Text=“ Oh , no , father .
#Text=She is going to be married .
#Text=That is all . ”
#Text=“ That is enough .
#Text=Who is the man ? ”
#Text=“ Reverend Mr. Stanhope . ”
#Text=“ Nonsense ! ”
#Text=“ Positively . ”
#Text=“ I never heard anything more ridiculous .
#Text=That saintly young priest ! Why , Dora will be tired to death of him in a month .
#Text=And he ? Poor fellow ! ”
